title: strong entry of calves for spring show
story: Some of the best commercial calves in the country will be forward at the Royal Northern Spring Show, held in conjunction with Aberdeen and Northern Marts.The annual event, which will be held at the Thainstone Centre on Wednesday, February , has attracted a strong entry of  calves from noted breeders.John and Craig Robertson from Newton of Logierait, Pitlochry, regularly dominate the show and sale, having scooped the supreme championship six times since . Last year, they sold the top price animal at £, for their champion heer and sold three others for £,, £, and £,.This year, the Robertsons have  calves entered including a full sister to last year’s top price heer.Huntly and Insch duo, Blair Duffton and Rebecca Stuart, will alsoto this year’s event with five calves, as will Ian Miller of Miller Farms, North Lurg, Midmar, who has four calves entered.Judging the commercial cattle entries, which will occur following the show and sales of bulls, will be well-known pedigree and commercial producer, Melanie Alford.John Angus, head of livestock at Thainstone, said: “The livestock sale element of the Royal Northern Spring Show is a fast-growing part of the event and we are delighted to be working once again with the Royal Northern Agricultural Society. The Spring Show is now recognised as the number one place for buyers from near and far to come and source quality calves with further showing potential.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"DIGG Councillor Martin Ford"  Councillors keen to prevent cuts viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: bus feedback events to return
story: Following the success of the event held in February , Bus Users Scotland willto Orkney this month to run another “Your Bus Matters” event to hear feedback on the bus services on the island. The events are open to everyone and will be held in Kirkwall and Stromness.The events give everyone the opportunity to provide feedback on what is working and what doesn’t about the local bus service. Representatives from Stagecoach will also be present to hear feedback on the services provided on the island.Greig Mackay, deputy director for Bus Users Scotland said: “We are looking forward to ing to Orkney to hear the views of the bus passengers. We were really pleased with the engagement at our event last year and look forward to hearing from more of the locals on the bus services on the island.”The two meetings will take place, later this month. Firstly, at Kirkwall Travel Centre on Monday, February , pm-pm, and then in Stromness on Tuesday, February , am-.pm.David Liston, managing director for Stagecoach North Scotland added: “We always welcome feedback on the services we provide and there is no better way to gather this than to host an event in partnership with Bus Users Scotland.#The feedback we received last year really helped us to develop improvements across the island demonstrated by the enhancements we made to services throughout the summer in . We are keen to hear what worked and what didn’t last year to help us shape our plans for .”If you can’t make the events you can still provide feedback to yourbusmatters@bususers.org.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. title: interactive hie roadshow comes to orkney
story: newsInteractive HIE roadshow comes to OrkneyFebruary ,  at : pm vw, px"  Starting here in Orkney this week, Highlands and Islands Enterprise is hitting the road to teach people how to outsmart online criminals and spot cyber threats.The free Cyber Sense on Tour workshops will visit businesses and communities throughout the Highlands and Islands using fun, interactive games to allow participants to get under the skin of hackers and learn the tricks of the trade.The tour starts in Orkney with two events, the first at Orkney Library this Tuesday, February , and the second at the NorthLink ferry Hamnavoe at the Stromness terminal on Wednesday.The interactive experience is open to all and will use innovative technology to create an immersive ‘point of view’ exercise, were participants can take the role of an employee, a cyber security professional and even a hacker to learn the tricks of the trade.Concepts such as ‘phishing’ will be explained and audiences will be taught to spot scams, dissect spurious emails and prevent hackers taking over their online lives.Working in collaboration with the National Cyber Security Centreand supported by the Scottish Government, the Cyber Sense sessions will provide a memorable and engaging way to discover how everyday actions can help protect people and companies from these evolving cyber dangers.April Conroy, project manager at Highland and Islands Enterprise, said: “As the way we work and live becomes more integrated online, it can be easy to take for granted how much important information we upload to the internet. Whether it’s our personal information on social media or important financial details, it’s vital that we’re aware of how to keep our safe and secure from cyber criminals.”“By really getting under the skin of these hackers, our Cyber Sense workshops can point out how to understand how these iniduals work. Through the games we’ve designed, attendees will be able to competitively play roles on both sides of a cyber-crime. This offers a unique perspective that can show just what preventative measures can be taken to outsmart these online criminals.”To learn more about the Cyber Sense on Tour event and to book a free place, visit www.hellodigital.scot cyber-sense- copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: power cable fault results in rackwick work
story: A faulty power cable, which links Orkney with mainland Scotland, has resulted in work being carried out at Rackwick Bay in Hoy.A Scottish and Southern Energy Networks spokesman said: “SSEN can confirm there is a network fault affecting one of the two electricity distribution cables that connect Orkney to the Scottish mainland. Following a fault investigation process, damage has been located to a section of the Pentland Firth East cable near the shore at Rackwick Bay, Hoy.“There is no impact to customer supplies on Orkney as a result of the fault and contingency measures are in place, including the potential operation of the backup power station at Kirkwall, supported by mobile generation sets, to ensure a safe and secure supply of electricity for customers.“SSEN is committed to ing the network to normal operation as soon as possible and has instigated a repair plan. Following the receipt of the necessary permissions from statutory authorities late last week, work to undertake a sectional cable replacement is now under way.#The statement added: #It is expected this work, which will be contingent on tidal flows and weather conditions, will be complete early next week, with the line re-energised shortly after.“As part of SSEN’s subsea cable inspection and replacement programme, a project to progress an end-to-end replacement of the Pentland Firth East distribution cable is already at an advanced stage of development, with cable installation and commissioning currently due to take place in autumn next year.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: views sought on cursiter quarry expansion plans
story: Orkney Islands Council is providing a further opportunity for the public to view and comment on plans to expand Cursiter Quarry in Firth.The Council is due to submit a planning application for the long-term development of Cursiter Quarry in Firth this Spring.As part of a -phased expansion plan designed to secure additional reserves the quarry could increase in size over the next three decades expanding into neighbouring fields. The planning application also covers landscaping and future restoration of the site.The application process is being handled by consultants AECOM.The council-owned quarry currently supplies stone and aggregate materials for Council roads and building projects as well as the local construction industry.  It extracts Devonian Flagstone which is highly suited to a range of crushed aggregate products, in particular as roadstone and aggregates, used for producing asphalt for road construction and maintenance, with the quarry being the only active producer of asphalt in Orkney.The activity at the quarry generates an income for the Council which is reinvested to provide and protect some of the vital services we provide in Orkney.The current quarry area is heading towards the end of its use and an expansion would safeguard supply of materials. Current output ranges between , and , tonnes of rock per year andapproved, the ha expansion will release approximately  million tonnes of additional resources, sufficient for another  years of production.Full details are available on the Council website at http:www.orkney.gov.uk Council C long-term-development-of-cursiter-quarry-in-firth.htmPersons wishing to provide comments on the proposed development can do so by writing to AECOM at fraser.blackwood@aecom or by post to Fraser Blackwood, APEX ,  Haymarket Terrace, Edinburgh, EH HD by  February .OIC says that, at this stage, comments made to Aecom are for the purposes of assisting with the scheme design and EIA process and as such are not representations to the Planning Authority. title: Black Isle cafes Brexit talk ban raises cash for worthy cause
story: The tongue-in-cheek bid to banish the Brexit blues at Rosemarkie Beach Cafeacute over the festive season saw customers warned theyrsquod face a pound finethey so much as mentioned a word seldom out of the headlines lately.Philip Eley, the long-standing cafeacute manager, explained. ldquoItrsquos just grim. People are so depressed. Folk come to the beach to get away from all those headlines about what the idiots in Westminster are up to, but it only takes one person to mention the B-word to ruin everyone rsquos bacon roll.Customers warmed to the idea and willingly dropped contributions in the bucket during visits to the Black Isle beauty spot.Mr Eleyrsquos partner, Verity Walker, made good on a promise to donate takings from the offbeat bucket collection to the Maggiersquos Highlands cancer care centre at Raigmore Hospital. It was gratefully accepted by fundraising manager David Walker, who is no relation. Ms Walker said: ldquoWe finally got the donations bucket and collecting can to the Maggiersquos Centre at Raigmore ndash they were quite heavy as we kept them on the counter a bit longer and you just kept on giving!ldquoMaggiersquos has helped a number of cafeacute customers and staff. They exist to support those who are affected by cancer, but that includes the families of those diagnosed. If you have never been in, please go and visit, itrsquos a lovely calm space amid the hustle and bustle of Raigmore.Tuesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Easter Ross gymnastics club storms to national success
story: GOLDEN girls from a flourishing Easter Ross gymnastics club thrilled judges to take a top title only six months after starting a new discipline.Fyrish Gymnastics Clubrsquos success at the  Scottish National TeamGym Championships held at Meadowmill Sports Centre in Tranent last weekend.came after the Alness-based Scottish Gymnastics club of the year made the eight-hour round trip to compete against well-established TeamGym clubs Irvine Bay, Forth Valley, Midlothian and Saltire.The discipline is credited with keeping gymnasts involved in the sport longer. The open level  team stole the show with their floor routine which clinched gold ndash and the Scottish national title, only six months after starting the discipline.Fyrish TeamGym head coach, Heidi Bavnhoslashj, said: ldquoItrsquos quite amazing, we were all crying! We started in August and now wersquove won! One of the judges came over to compliment us on our floor routine so I thought we might get a bronze ndash but never did I think we could win!ldquoThese girls, their parents and the club have provided the best support. We started off with eight gymnasts interested [in TeamGym] now we are up to . story: A BALLOT that could lead to strike action resulting in disruption to flights across the Highlands is due to open next week.The Prospect union confirmed it is going ahead with the ballot of air traffic control members at Highlands and islands airports in a dispute over pay with their employers, Highlands and Islands Airports Ltd .The ballot will run from February  to March  andmembers back industrial action, a series of one-day strikes could start on April  and run throughout the summer.As well as affecting Inverness Airport operations could also be disruptedat Benbecula, Dundee, Kirkwall, Stornoway, Sumburgh and Wick John OGroats.Members are also being askedthey wish to take action short of an all-out strike that could include working to rosters an overtime ban and refusing extensions to airport opening hours for non-medical flights.David Avery, Prospect negotiations officer, said: ldquoMembers do not wish to take this action but have been forced into this position by the refusal of ministers to engage with the issue of air traffic controllersrsquo pay.Hial is owned by the Scottish Government which last week said all staff had been given a pay rise which was a ldquosignicant improvement on previous years.Tuesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Parents blast council for not seeking cash to fix crumbling Dingwall school
story: SOME of the most vulnerable pupils in Ross-shire have been treated with "utter contempt" by the local authority which has misled parents and failed to seek "a single penny" of extra cash from the Scottish government.That was the damning indictment this week ahead of a crunch meeting on the future of St Clements in Dingwall before Highland Council sets its budget.Members of the parent-teacher council have already written to every single councillor urging them to take long-promised action to resolve severe problems with school building declared unfit for purpose by the governments childrens minister.The Scottish Government has confirmed the local authority has not sought funding for St. Clementrsquos from the the Scotland Schools for the Future programme.The next tranche of the pound billion announced last November will only be available from  leaving teachers and pupils enduring years more hardship in a building branded "Dickensian" by local MSP Kate Forbes.A Scottish government spokesman said: ldquoWe have been made aware that St. Clementrsquos is in poor condition, however it is the statutory responsibility of Highland Council to manage and maintain its school estate.ldquoThe Scottish government has provided signicant funding of over poundm in recent years towards five projects through its existing school building programme, Scotland Schools for the Future, all of which were Highland Councilrsquos priority projects for investment. Highland Council has not asked the Scottish Government for support in relation to St Clementrsquos.Christyna Ferguson, whose daughter suffering a series of complex health issues including autism attends the school, slammed the councilrsquos inaction "utter contempt for the already disadvantaged, vulnerable children".She said: "The Highland Council repeatedly told us that St.Clementrsquos appalling lack of facilities was due to a lack of Scottish government funding. Therefore it is misleading at best and shows not only non-compliance with their statuary obligations but utter contempt for the children."In the last year the Highland Council has taken no action to survey sites, secure funding or build a business plan despite assuring us they would."She insisted: ldquoHighland Council does have options in terms of funding solutions but they repeatedly refuse to engage in the process ndash again failing in their statutory obligations and causing unnecessary suffering and detriment to disabled children. It is incomprehensible to me that those with the power and the obligation in law can show such blatant disregard for disabled children."Dingwall-based MSP Kate Forbes said: "As the daughter of a former teacher at St Clementrsquos, I am in no doubt as to the poor condition of the buildings. It is remarkable the teachers are able to care for and teach the pupils in such a damp, cramped building.ldquoThere is a desperate need for a new building, delivered in consultation with parents and teachers. This is, of course, a matter for Highland Council who are statutorily responsible for school buildings but I think everybody wants to see a solution."I am more than happy to work with anybody and everybody to find a solution and would sincerely hope that wersquore not still talking about school buildings in another  years."Childrenrsquos minister Maree Todd, also a Ross-shire-based SNP MSP, said: "The school has not previously been prioritised by Highland Council in their capital spending plans despite being in a poor condition."Itrsquos nearly a year since I first raised concerns with the council so I look forward to meeting with councillors and officers at the end of this month to hear an update on progress. All children, especially those who are disadvantaged and vulnerable, deserve our help to enable them to, not only fulfil, but to exceed their potential. That is why it is vital that we can find the right solution for the pupils, parents and the wider St Clementrsquos community.A Highland Council spokeswoman said: "At this point in time we are addressing our capital plan for next year and the process is still ongoing. The council has been in dialogue with Scottish Government and highlighted the  school locations, including St Clements, which were identied by the council in March  as priorities for bids to Scottish Government. We are not aware of any Scottish Government Funding prior to ."Tuesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: People power sees safety measures considered for Tain junctions at last
story: HOPES are high that action will finally now be taken at two of the most dangerous road junctions in Easter Ross following a string of accidents and near-misses.Concerns about Tainrsquos two main junctions with the A prompted campaigners to claim a failure by roads chiefs to act would ldquoinevitably lead to someone being killed.Tain and Easter Ross councillor Derek Louden was joined by politicians from across the political spectrum in flagging up concerns, among them local MP Jamie Stone who said he had ldquopersonally witnessed more smashes than I care to remember and that ldquothere is something terribly wrong here.Campaigners had suggested a iety of possible measures, including reducing the speed limit, changing the road layout and even the installation of roundabouts ndash but their pleas fell on deaf ears.However, Transport Scotlandrsquos new area road safety manager, Richard Perry, has told Cllr Louden draft proposals have now been drawn up following an analysis of collisions at the north and south junctions by trunk road operator BEAR Scotland.Short-term measures could include enhanced signage, improved surfacing and better road markings.In the medium term, improvements to the bell mouth radius of the south junction will be considered.The possibility of reducing the speed limit on the bypass section to mph will also be investigated, but this would require statutory processes and consultation.Mr Perry said the construction of a roundabout could be considered, but would require agreement on funding.Cllr Louden told the Journal he was delighted to hear safety could finally be improved at the dangerous junctions.He welcomed the widening of the exits to allow lorries and buses to get onto the A without having to use the central reservation.And he said he was pleased to see a commitment to holding a consultation on reducing the speed limit on the bypass ldquoso that when accidents do occur, they are less likely to be fatal.He said he hoped efforts would begin early this year, as suggested in the letter.An initial review by roads chiefs noted a disproportionate number of incidents with buses and heavy goods vehicles exiting the minor road to enter the A into the path of approaching vehicles and ldquoa small number of poorly judged overtaking manoeuvres through the A junction.Tain Community Council previously said that simply blaming driver error was ldquoa cop out which failed to tackle the issue of two dangerous junctions.It warned the roadrsquos inclusion on the NC made accidents more likely.What do you think  Email us title: Ross nurses lead the way
story: Chrissie Laneand Lucy Heycockentered the gruelling Strathpeffer -hour mountain bike challenge with the aim of encouraging some of their patients and colleagues to embrace new challenges and experiences.The annual event near Strathpeffer sees riders tackle freezing temperatures,  hours of darkness and mile upon mile of frozen forest tracks.The dynamic duo were delighted with a podium finish. Macmillan cancer consultant nurse Chrissie, from Culbokie, said: ldquoWe work every day with amazing people living with cancer and are trying to support them to be active outdoors which has huge proven benefits to their health and recovery.ldquoMaking small or big changes to the amount of moving your body does throughout the day have immense benefits for people living with cancer.Theyrsquore promoting everything from short walks and cycle rides to hillwalking.Chrissie added: ldquoThe reason why we took part in the event was to try to be role models for older woman to just give experiences a try. All it needs is a gritty frame of mind and a sense of humour and fun when situations are not so pleasant.Chrissie and advanced nurse colleague Lucy, from Muir of Ord, were delighted with a podium finish, coming in an extremely credible third in the competitionrsquos female pairs category.Both Chrissie and Lucy hope that their success shows that you can take up and enjoy exercise, even doing an event like the challenging Strathpuffer, at any age.Tuesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Strathpeffer author pays tribute to charity that was there to help
story: A STRONG-WILLED Strath-peffer author who lost her sight aged  has paid tribute to the Highland charity that got her through the hardest days of her le.Emily Gray descended into misery after the  diagnosis, but said Sight Action showed her how to be happy again.The -year-old, whose childrenrsquos book Priscilla the Pig has just hit the shelves, said the support from the Inverness-based team was transformational.ldquoThey were brilliant, they changed my le, she said. ldquoIrsquove gained confidence to do everything.Miss Gray lost her sight when she was just  due to problems brought on by Type  diabetes.Looking back on the experience, which forced her to drop her music degree at Edinburghrsquos Napier University, Miss Gray, who now has a guide dog called April, said: ldquoI was in limbo. I didnrsquot do anything. I couldnrsquot go out by myself. It was not a nice place to be in...I was just existing and no more. All the hopes I had for the future were gone. I just felt like I had lost everything.The mum-of-one was referred by a specialist to Sight Action and the charityrsquos rehabilitation worker Brenda Smart became her strongest ally.The -year-old who is also the organisationrsquos client service manager was bowled over by Miss Grayrsquos resolve.ldquoWhen I first met her, I thought lsquothis is quite a determined young ladyrsquo. There were times when she doubted herself, but she put everything into it.Mrs Smart said cooking skills were important for Miss Gray.ldquoI showed her how to weigh out the recipes and all the things thatyoursquore sighted you do without thinking about it. Even the tidying up a bit, sweeping the floor, vacuuming. I showed her how to do that with a grid so she can tellshersquos got most of it up.ldquoAnd when she was pregnant we took out a baby doll and practised putting the baby in the carrier and changing the nappies on the doll. And when Harris was born she was absolutely brilliant. Irsquom really proud of her.Book publisher James Houghton of Olympia Publishing said: ldquoWhen considering the work, I was not aware Emily was blind. She is a great example of not letting a disability stand in your way.During pregnancy, Emily, who writes under the pen name Madeline Rose, mused over her own childhood and settled into writing her first story inspired by her mumrsquo Heatherrsquos tales of le on a farm in Dingwall using a voiceover computer programme.It is illustrated by self-taught Nairn artist, Sarah Jane Cumberford.Tuesday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: lesley riddoch what bbc scotland can learn from fiona bruce and question time
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...BBC Scotland needs to dump, not adapt, the tired format that dogs the UK#s flagship politics show, says Lesley RiddochShould BBC Scotland be cursing Question Time for muddying the broadcasting waters before its channel launch on  February – or should it be learning some big lessons The network flagship current affair programme got pelters last week after a former UKIP candidate appeared on the show for a fourth time – apparently breaking the programme’s own rules. Billy Mitchell, a flute band member who amassed  votes when standing for UKIP locally in , appeared previously in Kilmarnock and twice in Stirling, managing to ask a question hostile to the SNP each time. Amazingly, he then managed a fourth appearance in Motherwell and once again was picked to ask a question accusing the SNP of hypocrisy for offering no ‘hard’ or ‘soft’ option during the Scottish independence referendum. Surprisingly though, it wasn’t that robust rant that grabbed the headlines.Instead of featuring his anti SNP question, most papers focused instead on the frequency of Mitchell’s appearance, with the Sun observing it was “a feat so unlikely that bookies would give odds of several thousand to one against it happening.”That’s very signicant.Normally the mainstream media doesn’t register the complaints about bias of the SNP or wider Yes movement. But Mitchell’s presence as a “plant” was so blatant and the online outcry so precisethat no-one could ignore the claim. More problematic for Question Time- no-one wanted to.The stark truth is that the flagship programme of the British Broadcasting Corporation is now less popular amongst tabloid and broadsheet papers, north and south of the border, than a party that wants to leave Britain. That’s quite a feat and doesn’t represent any volte-face over independence by the mainstream media. Rather the press has marked Question Time out as the Weakest Link in the BBC’s current affairs offering.The rot set in quickly after the replacement of David Dimbleby by Fiona Bruce. In episode two, the “neutral” presenter wellied into guest Diane Abbott about Labour’s parlous state in the polls even though the party was level pegging with the Tories. Aunty was then forced to admit Fiona Bruce did refer to Abbott’s ‘personal and political relationships’ in the pre-show warm-up but insisted the presenter didn’t suggest the shadow home secretary got a frontbench role because of her previous closeness to Jeremy Corbyn.Astonishingly, Question Time seems to have got away with that highly unsatisfactory answer… until Motherwell.Scottish eyebrows were already raised at the unionist-heavy composition of the  Michael Forsyth of the Conservatives, Labour’s Anneliese Dodds, the SNP’s Fiona Hyslop, fashion model Eunice Olumide and journalist Hugo Rkind.One question for the SNP is why they let a Cabinet Secretary take part in such a nakedly skewed .My guess is that producers insisted Brexit not independence would be the main subject and thus the balance-demanding political faultline of the night. But independence was bound to come up and although Olumide is apparently a Yes voter– she tweeted later “Wish I had got the chance to say more about Scotland and independence” - Fiona Hyslop found herself isolated and outnumbered when Billy Mitchell was encouraged to hold forth. Olumide was excellent on the question of Liam Neeson and doubtless that’s why she was asked on. But independence needed another sharp-elbowed political operator ready to butt in without permission, because Question Time is a daunting arena in which only politicians and seasoned perfomers really thrive.Not my opinion but that of  year-old Jude Wilkinson who was an audience member some weeks earlier in Winchester“I did not speak up to disagree because speaking out is hard in an environment where unrepresentative audiences thunder applause for absurd arguments.The rush to insert adrenaline into rational debate is destructive to democracy. It is as though debate on matters of national policy is being done in a playground shout the loudest and you will win the argument. It felt utterly intimidating, stepping into the lion’s den.”And in Motherwell it was a highly unrepresentative lion’s den. Leaving the issue of independence to one side, North Lanarkshire like every other council area in Scotland backed Remain . Yet the programme was full of noisy Leave voters. This determination to impose a UK balance on each local audience is Question Time’s biggest problem.Its editors don’t recognise the importance of placewhich means they don’t recognise the reality of local opinion, which means they resort to the tawdry business of bussing in part of the audience almost every week to ensure “balance”. This is a practice the new weekly Scottish Question Time programme should not adopt. If it is broadcasting almost every week, then a genuinely Yes-leaning venue like Dundee can be balanced by visiting a genuinely No-leaning venue like Kelso the following week, achieving neutrality over time and – far more importantly – achieving credibility every week.If BBC Scotland’s new  programme encourages the full ersity of Scotland to be properly heard and explores domestic and international issues in addition to Brexit and independence it’ll be a dead-cert winner. But that now depends entirely on BBC Scotland dumping not tartanising the present, tired UK format. Thanks to Question Time’s recent string of failures on the neutrality front, authenticity is now far more important for the new BBC Scotland programme than aping Aunty to produce pointless screaming matches with imported bams or a dreary sameness. It would also be le-enhancing and politically importantBBC Scotland axed the UK ban on local places raising their own local issues. Worryingly though, it doesn’t look asthis new direction is likely to happen. According to respected health journalist Pennie Taylor, serial audience member Billy Mitchell was in the audience for a pilot episode of the new Question Time, filmed at Edinburgh’s Napier University last week.If true, that is unbelievable and BBC Scotland should admit its mistake. Otherwise the press and public will suspect the new channel is seeking notoriety, sensationalism and confrontation in a desperatye attempot to attract younger viewers. Not good for an important new programme on a publicly-funded new channel.Far better to go where UK Question Time fears to tread, and bring  discussions into the modern world, occupied by intelligent Scots in real places with real and erse political outlooks. ©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: brexit economic impact british households are 1 500 worse off than before referendum
story: Households in the UK have taken a #, hit since the Brexit referendum due to higher than expected inflation and stalling economic growth.The average income of homes across the country is £, lower than it had been predicted to be prior to the vote in , in which the UK opted to exit the European Union. window.twttr A new report said that the UK had experienced the sharpest slowdown in income growth of any comparable economy and higher than expected inflation levels – meaning Brits were spending much less than was forecaster.Contrast with the rest of the worldThe study, published by the Resolution Foundation said that households had £, less disposable income on average than they would have had under the Office for Budget Responsibilitypre-referendum forecast.It said that the economic “underperformance” that had been witnessed since  is a “largely UK-specic issue” and that the global performance had actually exceeded expectations.James Smith, research director at the Resolution Foundation, said: “Two and a half years since the UK voted to leave the European Union, the country’s post-Brexit position remains far from clear.• : Leave-backing expats in Spain regret their decision as Brexit looms“There has been much discussion about the impact of this uncertainty on businesses, but not enough about its effect on household incomes.“The UK’s stark under-performance on income growth since  – which has tailed off more than other advanced economies – has left UK households taking a £, hit to their living standards.Economic growth has fallen“As we approach Brexit day on  March, politicians in all parties need to recognise how much is at stake for family living standards and that how the country goes forward, not just where it is heading, matters for household incomes in the here and now.”The report corresponded with another announcement from the the Institute for Fiscal Studies which concluded that a no-deal Brexit would leave the UK budget deficit £billion higher over  years thanBritain had stayed in the EU.It said the UK would require an additional two years of the post -style strict austerity measures to plug the gap.Official figures have also shown that, in the final quarter of , the UK’s economic growth slowed as car manufacturing declined.Gross domestic product growth fell to . per cent between October and December, according to the Office for National Statistics, compared with . per cent growth in the previous quarter.Meanwhile, annual GDP increased by . per cent, the weakest it has been since .©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: scots health board wins permission to recruit more australian nurses
story: A Scots health board has won permission to recruit more nurses from Australia, to ease its staffing crisis.NHS Grampian already has  signed up from Down Under. Now it has persuaded the Nursing and Midwery Council to lt restrictions so it can employ more.The NMC agreed to relax the rules – meaning nurses and midwives do not need a year of experience on top of their university qualications to sit its exams.Senior nurse Elizabeth Wilson made the original scouting trip in , and believes it is a huge opportunity.She said it was clear Grampian offered an attractive alternative to many, despite the upheaval involved.“I think we are giving them the opportunity to use their skills, develop and get further training,” she said.“Many are aware of the NHS and are keen to explore what that experience is like. And there are a lot who have families back in the UK so have that connection.”Back in  it was revealed the board would be taking an unprecedented recruitment trip to scout potential nurses and midwives.During their -day trip, the nursing team spoke to more than  people who were interested in taking up posts.They have had the support of the Western Australia Department of Health in an effort to ensure nurses’ skills do not go to waste.A total of , nurses and midwives applied for a place on their two-year graduate programme, with just  able to secure a place, leaving , without a position.Jane Ewen, chief nurse in practice education and development, was one of the staff who made the trip.She said: “We built on our partnership with the department of health that was started last year, they are happy to collaborate with us, because they have a real surplus just now.”Last year, three of the four recruitment events were managed by external organisations. However, this year the board organised each event itself.The programme was a mix of presentations and interviews where those in attendance were given an insight into the health board and also the northeast region.The group even took over some items to give them an insight into the local and national culture – and were surprised at how many people recognised the Aberdeen FC top.Since then, Ms Wilson and Ms Ewen have been carrying out interviews via video calls, twice a day, beginning early in the morning because of the time dference.The NMC interim charge is part of a wider review into its overseas registration process for nurses and midwives trained outside of the EEA.Anyone who secures a visa will be asked to work for a minimum of two years, and will be provided with support to help sit the NMC exams, which consist of a theory and practical element.In August the board revealed it would be offering homegrown nurses the chance to go the other way and train in Western Australia.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: sse to study options for retail arm after more customers depart
story: SSE said it would examine options for its retail arm following the collapse of a merger with rival Npower as the Perth-based utility giant trimmed its earnings outlook and talked up its green credentials today.In a trading update, the group also pointed to competitive pressures as it saw the number of domestic energy accounts fall from . million at the end of September to . million in December.The firm is considering a standalone demerger and listing, a sale or ring-fencing of its energy services ision. It comes after SSE and Npower recently pulled plans to merge their retail businesses, blaming “challenging market conditions” and the UK government’s energy price cap.SSE warned that earnings per share would be lower than previously expected, coming in at a range of p to p, down from earlier estimates of p to p.The firm put this down to not being able to recognise income from the UK’s capacity market scheme following a court ruling.Chief executive Alistair Phillips-Davies told investors: “We continue to make good progress in our core businesses of regulated energy networks and renewable energy, complemented by flexible thermal generation and business energy sales.“We are also making progress in assessing the options for the future of the energy services business.“SSE has a clear strategy and good long-term prospects for its high-quality core businesses and assets that contribute to the transition to a low-carbon economy and will support the creation of value and delivery of our idend plan in the years to come.”Since pulling the Npower tie-up, SSE has sold its stake in two Scottish wind farms for £ million and disposed of half of its telecoms network business to Infracapital for up to £m.The group reiterated its intention to recommend a full-year idend of .p per share and to deliver on its five-year idend plan set out last May.Donald Brown, senior investment manager at Brewin Dolphin Scotland, said: “There’s a lot to be taken from SSE’s latest update.“The future of SSE Energy Services remains unclear, but options include demerging and listing the business, a sale, or an alternative transaction. However, it’s dficult to see who might be interested in buying the business, which has been in decline for some time.”He added: “While SSE expects to take a hit on earnings per share, meaning a sharp fall in expected earnings only three months after its previous forecast, the company’s £m share buyback scheme will be good news for shareholdersit provides share-price support.“Meantime, there will be relief at the commitment to the .p per share final idend.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

story: Plenty of onlookers were already on the streets as the squad made its first procession of the day from Islesburgh Community Centre, past the galley shed on St Sunniva Street and on to the Toll Clock Shopping Centre.In the gloom, the ranks of the Jarl#s Squad looked the part wearing emerald green kirtles with dragon mots underneath simple brown leather breastplates embossed with the same mot. story: As well as staging the dark comedy a block of drama workshops are being put on to help the youngsters involved develop the skills needed to take part.The ethos behind the workshops is that they will show people that they need not be put off by Shakespeare and any notions that his work is #dficult, incomprehensible, archaic, intellectual#. title: halcro johnston welcomes comments from senior snp minister on ferry funding
story: Signs have emerged of a softening in the Scottish government#s approach to fair ferry funding, with one Tory MSP insisting a senior SNP colleague has given backing for a better deal on leline links.Isles councillors have been left frustrated by the Scottish government#s funding offer following its budget, not least because of a shortfall in ferry funding.Complaints have been made by island leaders that the funding settlement, agreed last year, does not meet the full costs of running the internal ferries in Orkney and in Shetland.In the Western Isles the costs are met by the Scottish government as part of Clyde and Hebridean ferry service contract.But Conservative MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston had highlighted a visit to Orkney by the SNP #s constitutional relations secretary, Mike Russell.Jamie Halcro JohnstonAccording to a news release dispatched on Thursday, Mr Russell told The Orcadian newspaper: “I can take that back, and I can say to my colleagues, look this is a big issue in Orkney, and obviously it needs a resolution”.Mr Halcro Johnston welcomed the cabinet secretary’s acknowledgement that a resolution was required and urged one to be brought forward.“I welcome news of Mike Russell’s comments on fair ferry funding, and I’m encouraged by the intervention of a senior SNP minister. As a representative for Argyll and Bute, Mr Russell clearly understands ferry issues rather better than some of his government colleagues.#It comes after the Scottish government agreed to alter its spending plans with support from the Scottish Greens.The Greens said the Scottish government had agreed to alter its spending plans in exchange for support in getting the budget through.SIC leader Steven Coutts told The Shetland Times on Thursday: #At the moment we#re still waiting to see the final full detail on the back of the deal that was done between the Green Party and the SNP. We need to see what the figures actually mean.#There#s still no commitment on full and fair ferry funding, and that#s something we#ll want to press the government and Green Party on.#..
